TextEquiv.Unicode: THE BIRMINGHAM DAILY POST, FRIDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1857.
A Christmas Reverie.
(To be read before breakfast this morning, and again to‑ night, just before the candles come in.)

Amidst the echoes of harps, chiming down through nearly nineteen centuries,—in the strains of the angel song muttering through the departed years,—in the eternal blaze of that bright star which shone at Bethlehem,— amidst the sounds of the joyous shouts that proclaimed the great grand law—
“ All men are brethren !”

while the world is in gloom, eyes closed in sleep, and bells swing drowsily in dusky belfries, comes down to earth once more the old familiar Spirit of Christmas. Silently He comes, gliding on the wind gusts, away over the sea, through busy towns to forest glades, up amongst the hills, over moors, and commons, and lonely wolds, amongst strag‑ gling village homes, down into the dark mine, into the darker alley—everywhere! There is no such ghost as the Spirit of Christmas. Not in hoary old halls, in desolate houses, in crumbling abbeys, or haunted glades, does He only walk. With the dim stars, or the murky moon and the storm at midnight, He does not haunt alone. He comes into the streets and the sunlight, enters every home, plant‑ ing holly in the window panes, hanging up the mistletoe branch, and twining about the ivy sprays—those symbols that the men of old could understand, making them silent preachers of the law of love—Peace, Joy, Brotherhood !

There are sad changes to look upon since last He saw the world. Dear ones have departed; there are vacant chairs by the ﬁreside, unﬁlled places in the old pews; new made graves, and green grass growing over little mounds in the cold churchyard. There are corpses stark and ghastly in the sea; white bones bleaching, and mounds of mourned dead in Bengal. And the Spirit as He listens hears the mingled wails of the down‑stricken and the dying, and the thanks‑ giving song for deliverance waved across the sea from Oude’s terrible ﬁelds. He hearkens to the widow’s falling tear, and the prattle from little orphan lips comes upon his ear. He hears the unspoken thought, and speeds it on its way to dear ones and loved ones that are far oﬀ in other lands ; and in the wind gusts he brings back the answering prayers for happiness and blessing to the old house at home.

And the Christmas Spirit sees what Time has done—how Care has come to many, how brows have become wrinkled, and gray hairs have come, how Poverty has worked woe, and what sad things Misery has done; how great ones have fallen low, and riches have become rags. The Spirit of Christmas is sad as He looks upon such sorrow.

But He turns and He sees how Time has dealt again :— how little faces have sprung up about the hearth, how Care has been chased away by Joy ; how Misery has become con‑ tented ; how the lowly have been raised ; the sad made glad, Poverty become aﬄuent.

And the Spirit of Christmas has come faithful and true, to gladden sorrow, and make gladness joy. To the dying on the uneasy bed or upon the ﬁeld of war, in their ears He will sing the songs of a better land; He pours balm in horrid wounds, and lights up pallid faces with happy dreams of home. He stands beside the sick and places Hope beside their pillow. He binds up broken hearts, dries the widow’s tear, and seals a smile upon her lips. He puts his unseen ﬁnger upon old feuds and they die; upon enemies and they are no more. Hands long dissevered He joins in hearty grasp ; unkindly words, unbrotherly deeds, things done in hate He covers over with forgetfulness. He touches men’s icy hearts of selﬁshness and they thaw ; the frozen well‑springs of benevolence He sets free, and fresh and rippling in abundance they ﬂow again once more.

This day He puts his hand on every man. This day, when round the ﬁre friends meet, He whispers “ all men are breth‑ ren.” He takes the rich and well to do ; the man that can spare something from that which God has blessed him with: He takes him from his cosey room, his well‑ﬁlled table, and his comfortable hearth, down into dirty lanes, in amongst ﬁlthy alleys, where houses are black and grimmy, and crumb‑ ling in the damp; with squalid homes, windowless and miserable, where Poverty sits shivering by the emberless grate; where tottering Old Age, and Infancy in rags, with gnawing hunger at their hearts, look wistfully at the empty cupboard. The Spirit of Christmas makes him thank God, for mercies manifold, that his lot has been happier than theirs, and ﬁlling his heart with gratitude to HIM, He whis‑ pers that these squalid men and women, these poor neg‑ lected children, though they live in the vilest houses and are habited in rags, are his brethren and his sisters. And this day, before the bells ring their peals to call worship‑ pers together; before the church is open, or the song of praise begun; before the Preacher tells of the glorious coming down to earth of heaven; before the Great Book is opened, and the words of love are spoken, the Spirit of Christmas ﬁlling each heart, sends their bounty to the needy, kindles up ﬁres upon the hearth, spreads a table for the hungry, makes rags whole.

This is the work He has to do ; and the giver and the receiver are the more happy for what is done. And when this day the churches are deserted and silent, and the bells ring no more; when the Book is shut up and the preacher is gone; when thanksgiving songs are hushed, and the loving words have been said, and round festal tables, when the curtains are drawn, amidst bright lights and the roar‑ ing of the ﬁre, friends meet, and long dissevered families come together, the Spirit of Christmas will speak to every man, knocking at his heart, and asking if the law has been kept, whether his practice has been in accordance with the old truth—
“ All men are brethren !”

Whether there is one of the hungry he has fed, if one heart has been made the happier by his bounty: if he has sheltered one from the cold, cheered the weary, taken a burden oﬀ care, sent a ray of sunshine into a single home ? It will be a happy party, be sure of it, where every man can answer “aye !” It will be a merry, jolly, joyous circle by the ﬁre ; and the cheery ghost of Christmas will haunt them all the year. But to him of selﬁsh heart, that this day can show no deed of love; that from the poor on the other side passes by; be sure of this that the Spirit of Christmas lays on him a heavy doom. No merry laughter will light up that house, no luck attend it, no happiness come near it. Cold hearts will be about it, gloom spread upon it; the festive board will be a funeral feast, the wine gall, the food wormwood. Care and trouble, toil and sad‑ ness will be upon that home. It is a law that can never be broken without bringing down the pains of the Spirit of Christmas:—
“ All men are brethren !”

He that observes it, walks in its ways, takes to his heart the Spirit of Christmas, will ﬁnd long after this day has gone, that to him and his, like the faith of the olden time, it has been accounted righteousness.
CHRISTMAS DAY.
[We are sure that as many of our readers as have not seen the last number of the Saturday Review, will thank us for transcribing this seasonable article.]

Before we address our readers again, they will have kept their Christmas Day. The deeper and sublimer thoughts belonging to that day are the proper theme of the pulpit, not of the press, and it becomes the journalist only to express a hope that the pulpit may have the wisdom, at this pregnant time especially, to speak as to real and living men of the actual interests and duties of the hour. But to the politician and the journalist also—if they profess allegiance to the name of Christ, and regard their work as not alien to their profession‑special reﬂections and lessons are suggested by the return of the day on which peace and goodwill were ﬁrst proclaimed as the law of the world, and a new spirit came over the civil and social, as well as over the religious life of man. It is good for those who are always engaged in party controversies and conﬂicts to banish party feeling for a moment from the mind—to think of the common end which all good men pursue, though by diﬀerent roads—to look forward to the common haven in which all who have loved and served their kind will one day meet as friends for ever, and wonder that in the mist of earthly strife they once took each other for enemies. Now, too, when the Author of Christianity came into the world, a homeless peasant, to minister to others, is the season to remember that Christian polities is a code of duties, rather than of rights. Now is the season to think how worthless are all political advantages, how trivial are all political disputes, compared with that which concerns the spiritual life while we celebrate the advent of a Master who, though he brought with him the truth that makes us free, was content to pay tribute to a foreign despot and to die the death of a slave. Now is the season for those whose work must always be more or less embittered by faction and contention, to lay aside faction and contention for a moment, and enter in spirit into the great communion of mankind.

This Christmas is, alas ! far from a “ Merry Christmas” to many families, or to the whole nation. By many a hearth, instead of the voice of joy and feasting, there is the voice of mourning for aﬄiction the most poignant that can enter into the heart of man. In many a house, a though of unutterable anguish has taken the place of a beloved face. Many a parent needs to be comforted by the reﬂection that those who fell in duty are not cut oﬀ, but taken early home Many a widow needs to be assured that aﬀection is not ended but ratiﬁed by death. The nation, too, is engaged in what must be regarded as a strange and alien work for a Chris‑

tian people. It is struggling to maintain its dominion as a conquering power over another nation. We believe and trust that the empire for the maintenance of which we are contending is a beneﬁcent one, such as it is our duty to maintain, and that Providence has given it for high pur‑ poses into our hands. But to escape the spirit of heathen self‑aggrandisement and heathen pride, we have need of the best resolutions that man can form or reason inspire to make our dominion, when rëestablished, one not of selﬁsh tyranny and rapacity, but of Christian charity and love. We are engaged, as a Christian nation, in the alien work of conquest; and we are engaged in the still more alien work of retribution. That retribution is, indeed, righteous; and so far as it is righteous, it is our duty to inﬂict it, for we are to these criminals in the place of the Magistrate, and bear not the sword in vain. Punishment is necessary to prevent renewed horrors, and to stamp if possible for ever on the Eastern mind the wrath of Heaven against demoniac crime. It is necessary for the guilty men themselves, for whom, since they have put themselves out of the pale of humanity, it is better, in the eye of mercy itself, to die than live. But far be it from us to wield even the righteous sword in a spirit of mere vindictiveness. Still farther be it from us to involve the innocent in the same storm of blind vengeance with the guilty. We must stiﬂe with indignant horror cries for wholesale butchery—else it was not for us that Christ was born into the world.

But there is another source of unhappiness which will throw a gloom over many Christian hearths, and which is due not to our enemies, but to ourselves. We mean the loss of property arising from gambling speculation. It cannot be doubted that the craving desire to become sud‑ denly rich has deeply infected not only coarse minds, but those which have had every advantage of education and religion, and which might have been expected to be content with competence, with aﬀection, and the life to come. All persons and classes seem smitten with the desire to reap that which they have not sown, and to gain, by the cast of the die, what they have not earned by the work of their hands or the labour of their brain. The old man brings his savings, the widow brings her mite, to the great gaming‑table, to play for vani‑ ties and luxuries which not only religion but reason ought to teach us to despise. And now their sin has found them out, and the lottery (for it is nothing else,) proves to have, like other lotteries, some prizes and many blanks; the prizes mostly for the long purses of the rich, the blanks for the short purses of the poor. This is rather a strange calamity to have befallen a nation which accepts, and prides itself above its neighbours in accepting, as its rule of life, a book declaring wealth to be a peril, poverty a blessing, and the love of money to be the root of all evil. To strain too far the strong sayings of the New Testament about money would be foolish. The result of such over‑straining is an entire divorce between the impracticable theory of the pulpit and the practice even of the preacher’s life. Fair commercial enterprise—success in fair commercial enterprise—is not condemned by Scripture. Fair commerce is a noble calling, and can boast as pure and lofty names as any in the world. It is as much ordained by Providence—it is as divine—as any other necessary part of the temporary estate of man. It serves obviously, though indirectly, the higher purposes of the Creator of the moral world, and knits together nations in bonds not only of mutual beneﬁt, but of peace and of goodwill. It works steadily, with silent power, to break down the barriers of nature which divide people from people, and to mould together the great com‑ munity of mankind. The merchants of England, as Chris‑ tian men, may be proud of their noble calling. England, as a Christian nation, may be proud of her commercial greatness. But neither the merchants of England as Christian men, nor England as a Christian nation, can be proud of the conduct that has led to the present disasters. All Christians must regard such conduct not only with the deepest regret for the suﬀerings it has produced, but also with the deepest shame.

Want, too, has fallen, as a consequence of these disasters, on many of the working classes. Many mechanics are de‑ prived, and must see their families deprived, of bread at this happy and festive season—and that not only by their own improvidence in neglecting to lay by part of their high wages against the evil day, but partly also through that rash and criminal covetousness of their better‑educated and more responsible employers which has given manufactures an unnatural impulse, followed too surely by an unnatural want of work. Those who bid the suﬀerers be patient and resigned under their suﬀerings, and look forward hopefully to better times, do well so to counsel them. They can only put oﬀ the revival of commerce, and prolong their own destitu‑ tion, by attempting to break the law, and by creating another panic in the sensitive system on the security and conﬁdence of which their lot depends. But it should be remembered also that, if it is the duty of the mechanic to endure, it is the duty of the rich man to relieve. The mechanic’s master, and the chiefs of commerce generally,owe him that wise guidance which is virtually given by sound trading. They have, through their haste to be rich, failed in their duty in this respect; and they must not regard the misery that ensues among their dependants as if it were a visitation of Providence, or a defect in nature, which they are not concerned to provide against or relieve. The laws of the natural distribution of wealth, which economists demon‑ strate and journalists preach, are truths indeed—high and fruitful truths—and the system they form is one of the most admirable proofs of the beneﬁcence and wisdom of the Creator. But the laws of the distribution of wealth are not the laws of duty and aﬀection. They are but the hard framework of society, which must be clothed upon with tissues of a softer kind. They are imperfect in themselves, and must be supplemented by the gentler code of benevo‑ lence and mercy, which, in this case of misguided mechanics, carries with it also the rule of justice. Let us have peace and order, and economical science, by all means—but not selﬁsh neglect of misery, wrapping itself in the cloak of science. Government has been applauded for stepping in, against economical science, to stop the spread of suﬀering among the rich ; and Christianity, by all its voices, demands that the same measure should be meted to the poor.
Poetry.
SANTA FILOMENA.
BY H. W. LONGFELLOW.
Whene’er a noble deed is wrought, Whene’er is spoken a noble thought, Our hearts, in glad surprise, To higher levels rise.
The tidal wave of deeper souls Into our inmost being rolls, And lifts us unawares Out of all meaner cares.
Honour to those whose words or deeds Thus help us in our daily needs ; And, by their overﬂow, Raise us from what is low !
Thus thought I, as by night I read Of the great army of the dead, The trenches cold and damp, The starved and the frozen camp,
The wounded from the battle plain, In dreary hospitals of pain, The cheerless corridors, The cold and stoney ﬂoors.
Lo ! in that house of misery A lady with a lamp I see Pass through the glimmering gloom, And ﬂit from room to room.
And slow, as in a dream of bliss, The speechless suﬀerer turns to kiss Her shadow, as it falls Upon the darkening walls.
As if a door from heaven should be Opened, and then closed suddenly, The vision came and went— The light shone and was spent.
On England’s annals, through the long Hereafter of her speech and song, That light its rays shall cast From portals of the past.
A lady with a lamp shall stand In the great history of the land, A noble type of good, Heroic womanhood.
Nor even shall be wanting here The palm, the lily, and the spear— The symbols that of yore Saint Filomena bore.
—Atlantic Monthly.
WHO IS GOING TO CANADA ?

It is very remarkable, and should suﬃce of itself to prove the permanence of the prosperity to which Canada has attained, that, notwithstanding the severity of the mone‑ tary crisis in the neighbouring republic and in the mother country, none of the provincial banks have stopped pay‑ ment, and very few commercial ﬁrms have been at all aﬀected by it. Facts like this oﬀer the strongest induce‑ ment to those who contemplate emigration to make Canada their destination, and prove how reliable are the accounts sent home by Mr. Buchanan, the Government Emigration Oﬃcer at Quebec, whose latest returns on this subject intending emigrants of all classes will do well to study with attention. They show that the condition and prospects of those of the immigrants of the year who were ﬁtted for removal to a country like Canada by education and previous condition are most satisfac‑ tory; labourers of industry and intelligence, especially agriculturists, were in general demand throughout the pro‑ vince during the spring and summer, and in many districts the farmers complained of great inconvenience and loss for want of this description of labour. Domestic servants, especially females, were universally enquired for, and readily found employment at good wages. The rate of wages for mechanics averages from 5s. to 8s. a day. Day labourers get from 3s. to 5s. a day; farm servants from 2s. to 2s. 6d., with board, and boys and girls get the same. Female servants get from 10s. to £1. a month. With regard to this useful class it may be observed that, in the United Kingdom, females are half a million in excess of males, and it behoves those who interest themselves in the condition of the ill‑paid and over‑worked needlewomen and others to consider whether it would not be better to facilitate their emigration to Canada than to contend longer with the increasing diﬃculty of providing employment for them at home. Both for domestic servants and for agricultural labourers and small farmers no country oﬀers so many solid and permanent advantages as Canada. As in all new countries, land increases so

rapidly in value that the small farmer, if his loca‑ tion be well chosen, becomes a landed proprietor in a few years. Around him grow new circumstances, which confer upon him enhanced prosperity, and create an increased demand for the manufactures of the mother country, in return for the produce he exports. The land in Canada is good, and it may be regarded for the present as inexhaustible. Agriculture is the source of all wealth, even where there are neither mines nor cotton mills. The necessities of the farmer create a large body of mechanics around him. This is now the case in Canada, but as yet the circumstances of the colony forbid concentration, and hence the necessity of emigrants informing themselves where their labour is most needed. This is not always the most promising in the same district. During the past sea‑ son the best opening for emigrants was found eastward of Toronto; and those who leave their arrangements for inland transport to be completed at Quebec may save a portion of the expense by adopting a stopping place which oﬀers the most extensive and likely ﬁeld of employment.
No notice of Marriage or Death can be inserted unless authenticated by the name and address of the sender.—Notices of Births are charged for as advertisements.
MARRIED.
On the 22nd inst.. at the Parish Church, Yardley, (by the Rev. H. Gwyther,) Mr. George Henry Tomlinson, to Mary Anne, only daughter of the late Mr. Thomas Dallaway, both of that place.
DIED.
On the 22nd inst., in Whitmore Lane, Small Heath, aged 64 years, Mr. Joseph Parsons, deeply lamented by his family and friends.
On the 23rd inst., of scarlatina, Frederick, second son of Mr. David Morgan, of Victoria Street, Small Heath, aged four years.
On the 22nd inst., at Edgbaston, aged one year and ten months, Lucy Anne, second daughter of Mr. Cornelius Robins, of this town.
On the 18th inst., at her son‑in‑law’s, (Mr. W. Richards,) deeply and sincerely regretted by her family and friends, aged 87 years. Hannah, relict of the Rev. E. Oakes, formerly of this town.
On the 16th inst., of inﬂammation of the lungs, Maria, the beloved wife of Mr. James Warren, of Upper Marshall Street, in this town.
On the 20th ult., Ann, relict of Mr, John Hawkins, of Tanter Street, in this town, deeply regretted by all who knew her.
On the 16th inst., Mr. Richard Bond, of New Street. West Brom‑ wich; also, on the 20th inst., Ann, wife of Mr. Richard Bond.
On the 16th inst., aged 62 years, Mr. Thomas Penn, furnace manager, Madeley Court, Madeley.

MIDLAND INSTITUTE.
A

Deputation from the Council of the Midland Institute having waited upon the Chairman of St. Thomas’s Ward Election Committee, with a view to obtain its coöperation in Canvassing for Donations and Subscriptions for the Institute, a Meeting of St. Thomas’s Ward Election Committee was held on the 17th December, 1857, and
Unanimously Resolved—
That the WARD be CANVASSED, and the following Gentlemen be appointed as a Sub‑committee for the purpose.
Mr. Councillor Brown Mr. Councillor Sturges Mr. Councillor Poultney Mr. Robert Edmonds Mr. C. Lewis Mr. J. G. Hinde Mr. J. Cresswell Mr. A. Thompson
Mr. Talbot Mr. Endean Mr. F. Mole Mr. J. C. Wynn Mr. J. Ingram Mr. J. Avins Mr. W. Bennett Mr. W. Knowles.

HE Proprietor of these popular Saloons announces that a GRAND MASK BALL,

On a scale of unusual magniﬁcence, will be held on MONDAY EVEN‑ ING NEXT, (Monday after Christmas Day,) when he hopes to be again favoured with the liberal patronage he has so long enjoyed, and which he will be most anxious to merit the continuance of by every attention he can give to his Visitors when they seek the enjoyments it will be his special study to make his Establishment always aﬀord them.
Admission, 1s.; Spectators, Gallery, 6d.

Public Amusements.
“SAVE ASTON HALL !”
T

HE Committee beg to inform the Shareholders that in consequence of having to pay the Proprietors the First Deposit of £3,500. at Christmas. and of the absolute necessity of their entering into possession of the place at that time, in order to make arrangements for an
INAUGURAL FETE IN THE SPRING, It has been resolved to make the call for a SECOND DEPOSIT OF 2s. 6d. PER SHARE.

Shareholders who have not yet paid their ﬁrst deposit, are earnestly requested to do so at once, as the measures to be taken by the Com‑ mittee in laying out and beautifying the place will thereby be materially assisted.

Shareholders may, if so disposed, pay any number of calls at the same time; and the Committee would urge upon all who have the interest of the movement at heart, to avail themselves of this power in helping them in their arduous undertaking.
Oﬃce open from Ten a.m. till Nine p.m.
By order.
J. A. LANGFORD, Sec. pro. tem.
Odd Fellows Hall, 13, Temple street. 1505

O‑MORROW (SATURDAY) MORNING and EVENING, December 26, and on MONDAY MORNING and EVENING, December 28th, and also on the EVENINGS of TUES‑ DAY and WEDNESDAY, December 29th and 30th,
SAM COWELL WILL GIVE A SERIES OF HIS POPULAR CONCERTS, ASSISTED BY MISS SUSAN WIGHT, MR. BROOKHOUSE BOWLER, AND MR. W. F. BRIDGEMAN.
Stalls, 2s. ; Area, 1s.; Gallery, 6d.

The MUSIC to the whole of SAM COWELL’ SONGS, and the 1s. and 6d. SONG BOOKS, ARE NOW ON SALE at Tonks’s, Town Hall Printing Oﬃce, 85, New Street, where Tickets and Places for the above Concerts can be secured.
HOWES AND CUSHING’S GREAT UNITED STATES CIRCUS.
THE LARGEST ESTABLISHMENT IN THE WORLD, NUM‑ BERING UPWARDS OF 200 MEN AND HORSES.
T

HIS Gigantic CIRCUS, ﬁtted out in New York expressly to travel in Europe, arrived in Liverpool April 24th, 1857, WILL OPEN in Birmingham SATURDAY NEXT, December 26, 1857, for a short Season of four weeks, in the new beautiful and commodious Brick Building, situated in Moor Street, and capable of accommodating 3,500 Persons, and recently erected by S. Briggs, Esq., at a cost of £3,000., with a
BETTER AND LARGER COMPANY Than has ever before been concentrated in any Ring, either in Europe or America.
THERE WILL BE TWO GRAND PERFORMANCES EACH DAY, AND NO POSTPONEMENT.
Day Entertainments fully equal to Nights.
Morning Performances commence at Two o’clock; Evening at a quar‑ ter past Seven.

N.B.—Admission, (prices reduced for Winter Season:) Boxes. ONE SHILLING; Pit and Gallery, SIXPENCE; Reserved Seats, TWO SHILLINGS. Children under Ten, half‑price to Day Performances in Boxes and Reserved Seats only.
Among the principal ARTISTS will be found :—
Mr. DAVID RICHARDS, The great Prairie Rider, on his naked white Steed, has no equal in his particular line.
Miss ROSE MADIGAN, The American Prima Donna Equestrienne, will appear at each perfor‑ mance and go through her beautiful act of Horsemanship.
Mr. GEORGE BACHELOR, The best Summersault Leaper in any country, will also appear as two and four‑horse Olympian.
Master JAMES MADIGAN, The famous Single Horse Rider, will do Summersaults on horseback with the same ease that others do on the ground.
Messrs. HOLLAND and MURRAY, the Roman Brothers, in their unequalled performance.
The well‑known favourite Clown, JOE PENTLAND.
Mr. HENRY MADIGAN, Mr. ARMSTRONG, Mr. ROSSERTON, Mr. BAXTER, and Twenty others, who will be brought forward from time to time.

At each Performance during the Holidays, the North American INDIAN SAVAGES will appear; also, the ﬁnest Trick Horse in England. “BLACK EAGLE;” and the celebrated educated Mules, “PETE” and “BARNEY,” in a Performance that cannot be wit‑ nessed elsewhere, and pleases better than any act ever produced.
The celebrated Tribe of REAL BEDOUIN ARABS
Are attached to this Establishment, and go through their Wonderful Feats at every Performance; pen cannot describe or pencil pourtray the wonderful performances of these Children of the Desert.
And ﬁnally, the Managers conﬁdently assure the Public, that the expense attending the above combination has never before been under‑ taken by any Equestrian Establishment in England.
AGENT, H. M. WHITBECK.
CONCERT HALL, COLESHILL STREET, BIRMINGHAM.
PROPRIETOR, H. HOLDER.
IMPORTANT ENGAGEMENTS.
POWERFUL ATTRACTION FOR THE CHRISTMAS HOLIDAYS.
GREAT COMBINATION OF TALENT.

H. HOLDER begs most respectfully to announce to his numerous Patrons and the Public, that the Concert Hall is now completed, ren‑ dering it the most spacious and elegant Room in the United Kingdom. The Entertainment is varied each evening, supported by Artistes of acknowledged talent.
O
N MONDAY NEXT, December 28th, and during the week, ENGAGEMENT of those talented Artistes,
MR. AND MRS. G. H. GEORGE, In their popular Illustrations. Also Engagement of MESSRS. LAWRENCE AND STOLBER, The celebrated Albanian Minstrels.

UNPRECEDENTED SUCCESS OF THE NEW CHARACTERISTIC BALLET DIVERTISSEMENT, LA NORMANDIE, or the SAVOYARDS, Produced under the direction of M. GILMER, supported by MISS LAURA SANDERS, MISS OLIVIA SHARPE, And a numerous Corps de Ballet.
The following Artistes will also appear:—
MISS SEYFRIED, The accomplished Vocalist, who will each evening sing Mr. E. Farmer’ popular new Song, “The British Volunteer.”

MR. BELLHOUSE, The powerful Basso.
